DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Climb
DOC.TEXT: The unabating pre-Christmas cold snap drove heating oil futures prices to their highest closing levels in nearly four years on Monday, and crude oil futures soared above $22 a barrel for the first time since April. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the January contract for No. 2 heating oil climbed 4.24 cents to 74.66 cents a gallon in active trading. Domestic heating oil last closed higher on Jan. 7, 1986, when it hit 75.67 cents a gallon. The January contract had risen 3.14 cents a gallon on Friday. The January contract for West Texas Intermediate, the leading grade of U.S. crude, rocketed $1.12 to settle at $22.22 per 42-gallon barrel. It was the highest level since April 20, when the near-month crude contract closed at $24.65 a barrel, according to a New York Merc statistician, who asked not to be identified by name. The January contract rose 45 cents a barrel on Friday. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for January ended the session at 54.51 cents a gallon, up 1.71 cents from Friday's settlement. The unleaded gasoline contract rose 1.19 cents on Friday. ``We are seeing weather-driven markets right now, led by heating oil,'' said Evan Baron of the energy group at Elders Futures Inc. in New York. He said the cold weather that has swept across much of the nation in the past week is usually not seen until January or February. ``Heating oil distributors were simply not prepared for this kind of extended cold weather this early in the season,'' Baron said. William Byers, director of futures research at Bear Stearns & Co. Inc., said cold weather in Europe several weeks ago inhibited shipments of oil products, adding to the problems when the weather worsened in the United States. In addition, he said, inventories of home heating oil are slightly below what they were a year ago. Byers said one reason for the jump in crude prices was that the January contract expires at the end of trading on Tuesday. Other contract months rose but finished below $22 a barrel. He said reports of continued turmoil in Panama failed to exert as much influence on the market as on Friday, when the reports were cited as a major factor in the rise in crude prices.
